The second thing also probably has a lot to do with PTSD, too, and I really wanna see where this goes because I have very difficult to treat PTSD and "free floating" anxiety. Mental health professionals have trouble understanding that this anxiety is not a choice or caused by anything specific.

It could be that this is the cause of panic disorder, a neurological disorder that causes panic attacks and anxiety without the typical anxiety triggers in typical disorders. And, it would make sense for PTSD too and "hypervigilance" as well. Also explains why depressants/sedatives work well for people who struggle with these issues (like myself) because it limits the response of key areas of the brain responsible for threat detection and perception, giving relief from overwhelming feelings that hijack the rest of the brain and body's activity.

It is theorized that some strains of marijuana do this too, and that this helps with PTSD because it allows patients to more safely confront their triggers and program new, healthier chains of neurons associated with those things, and in turn cause the old and dysfunctional chains to deteriorate due to disuse, and creating a preference in the brain for the new chain through positive neurochemistry (ei more stable and functional levels of dopamine, serotinin, etc).

I believe we really need to laser focus research onto this new discovery and the implications with mental health, especially PTSD, which can cause symptoms commonly misdiagnosed as anxiety and depression, and the effects that different chemicals and treatments have on this area of the brain, especially substances people with PTSD feel helps with their symptoms, and what they and their doctors observe improving the results of treatment.

PTSD is a terrible illness, and the fact that there are only a few FDA approved treatments for PTSD specifically is very sad and very problematic. PTSD holds me back in about every major and minor part of my life, one way or another, and I need a better prognosis. I believe I was born with a brain that has the particular section responsible for perception and response to threat VERY sensitive, easily manipulated (woo high neuroplasticity), and very easily overstimulated.

I am prepared to do whatever I can to contribute to these efforts!

As someone who is both a neuroscience/genetics geek and a sufferer of generalized anxiety disorder, I've always been highly interested in the neurological basis of mental disorders. I always thought it was hyperactivity of the amygdala that caused anxiety, so when I saw this video saying it was hyperactivity of the sgACC, my curiosity was piqued. I looked into some neuroanatomy and wouldn't you know it, the sgACC feeds directly into the amygdala. As an input!

To borrow a term from my actual career as a software developer, this seems to suggest that anxiety disorders -- or at least GAD -- might be a case of GIGO: Garbage In, Garbage Out. In other words, the amygdala isn't the problem, it's just getting garbage input from the sgACC. Now I feel bad... all these years I've been angry at my amygdala, and the poor thing was trying its best and just working with bad data!
